section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards, paper bag, toy cat, carrot, comb, necklace, napkin, nickel, drawing supplies, three paper circles (per child), black construction paper, scissors, premade insect

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Rabbit Moon. We noticed the letters n, i, and c in the words we saw.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Nn, Ii, Cc Alphabet Cards Display pictures for I, N, and C. Nut begins with the letter N. What sound does the letter N make? Iguana begins with the letter I. What sound does the letter I make? Car begins with the letter C. What sound does the letter C make?

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Let’s find something that begins with /i/.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Do the Activity Have children take turns choosing objects. For each object, ask whether it begins like iguana. Then ask, What does begin like? Have children place the object under the correct picture.

After all objects have been sorted, say: None of these objects begins like iguana, but I have something that does. Show the insect you made. What does insect begin like? Invite children to make insects.
Extend Demonstrate and have children follow these directions:
section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Cut out six legs. Glue them on.
Make a face for your insect.
section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat As children work, say, /i/, /i/, insect.
Practice Writing Letters Nn, Ii, and Cc Help children practice writing the uppercase and lowercase letters. Provide help as necessary.

Focus on each picture. Ask children to repeat it with you, emphasizing the initial sound. Then help children identify the letter on the back of the card. Invite children to trace the letter with their finger, and then say the beginning sound together.

Assign partners and challenge children by providing the Alphabet Books for N, I, and C for children to share and work on together. Ask them to find the picture of an insect and the word. Then name other pictures and words for children to find in each of the books.

Children learning English as a second language whose home language does not use a Latin (Roman) alphabet may have difficulty differentiating between Ii and Ll and Nn and Mm. Assist them as needed to see the differences in these letters. Also note the English/Spanish cognates insect and insecto, and the word iguana that is the same in both languages.

Some children have difficulty distinguishing between /i/ and /e/, so emphasize and exaggerate the movement of your mouth as you say beginning sound /i/. To help children remember the sound, have them repeat several times, “/i/, /i/ insect.”

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65560-5. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Large black construction paper stars, yellow dots and white dots, glue.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We read about the Rabbit in the moon who was responsible for turning wishes into stars. And even though he left the moon for a time, he went back when he noticed that the stars were missing from the sky.
We talked about how important it is to be responsible for the materials and jobs we do in our preK.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-talk: Today we are going to make twinkling wishing stars. Then we are all going to be responsible for cleaning up the materials. Are you ready? Here are steps to follow.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Glue lots of dots to your star to make it twinkle.
Stop when you hear me clap three times.
Then take responsibility for putting away the leftover dots.
Put all the yellow dots on one plate and all white dots on the other plate.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Give each child a black construction paper star, and a handful of cut-out yellow dots and white dots—more than they need, so there will be something to clean up.
Extend As you see children finishing, clap three times. Encourage them to clean up and remind them where to put the dots they didn’t use.
Talk About Being Responsible Talk about why it’s important to take care of classroom materials. Ask children to name some classroom jobs and the materials they need to take care of.

Following the steps for making the twinkling wishing stars may be a challenge. Instead of having children follow the steps, do one step at time with them. When it’s time to clean up, have them first put all the yellow dots in one plate, and after that put away all the white dots.

Invite children to draw pictures of themselves taking care of classroom materials in one of the Independent Centers. Help them label the items they show in their drawings. Ask them to say the letter and sound of each.

Children whose home language is not English may not understand what each step entails. Make sure when you model the steps that these children know what is expected. You might want them to repeat or rephrase each step after you say it.
Some children may need help with this activity. If they have trouble pasting small items, replace the yellow and white dots with star or dot stickers that may be easier for them to manipulate.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65560-5. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Construction paper booklets with three black pages and a white cover; cutout moon shapes (full moon, half moon, and crescent moon); glue; star stickers.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: We read Rabbit Moon about a rabbit who lived on the moon and turned wishes into stars. Sometimes when his friends on Earth looked up, they could see all of the moon, a full moon. Sometimes they could only see half of the moon, a half moon. Sometimes they could only see a sliver of the moon, a crescent moon.
Today we will look at moon pictures and then make them in the nighttime sky.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show the picture cards one at a time and ask the question on the back of the card, offering help as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of each card to help children identify the different shapes of the moon.
Create Give each child a construction paper booklet. Have children observe as you write the title on the cover: The Moon. First model and then have children follow these directions:
section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Glue a full moon to the first page.
Glue a half moon to the second page.
Glue a crescent moon to the third page.
Decorate each page with star stickers.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About the Moon Remind children that Rabbit Moon is a narrative, a made-up story. Then talk about the real moon and share with them that only 12 astronauts have walked on the real moon.

Young children most likely do not have a lot of experience seeing the nighttime sky. When you show the Activity Cards, make sure children understand that these are pictures of the real moon that people see when they look up at the nighttime sky.
Challenge children to draw pictures of themselves as astronauts walking on the moon. Help children write a sentence about their pictures.

Before you do the activity, present the cards and name the different phases of the moon that are shown. Reviewing the language before doing the activity will be helpful for children whose home language is not English.

Children may not understand the terms first, second, and third. Help them by labeling the page with three different stickers. Then you can say, Glue the full moon on the page with the circle sticker, Glue the half moon on the page with the square sticker, and Glue the crescent moon on the page with the heart sticker.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65560-5. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Blue construction paper, drawing supplies, cotton balls, glue

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the Big Chart of Big Ideas: Daytime/Nighttime and we saw how the mountains, the country, and the city look in the daytime and the nighttime.
Today we will make pictures to show a daytime sky. What do you think we might see?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Elicit that they might see the sun, clouds, planes, and birds. Demonstrate how to use glue and the cotton balls to make clouds. Then complete your picture by drawing a sun, some birds, and a plane.
Set Up Give each child a sheet of blue construction paper and have them use cotton balls to make clouds and then draw other things they might see in a daytime sky.
Extend After children complete their pictures, encourage them to present their pictures to the group and name the things they included.
List for children the names of things they drew. Then read the list together. Invite children to say the beginning sound of each word after you name it and label their pictures with the letter.
Challenge their imaginations and have children tell what their cloud shapes remind them of.
Talk About the Sky Talk about how Earth gets light from the sun in the daytime and light from the moon and stars at night. Encourage children to talk about the things they like to do in daytime.
Young children may need help using the cotton balls. You may need to apply the glue for them and then have them direct you as to where to place each cotton ball.
Children may enjoy making more cloud pictures and using their imaginations to describe them. After they have finished, help children write stories about their cloud pictures.

Allow time for peer-to-peer conversation. Encourage children to work in pairs, talking about what they are adding to their pictures of the daytime sky. Remind children to take turns listening and speaking. Remind children that it’s fine to use some words from their home language if they find it helpful.

Children can use various art supplies to add more details to the to their daytime sky pictures. Besides crayons, supply stickers of planes, birds, and the sun, or simple shape stickers that children can use to create their own pictures.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65560-5. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
